conclusion: Initial velocity components are calculated using trigonometric functions.
In a uniform magnetic field, the charged particle moves in a circle of radius r = mv/(qB).
The speed is constant in a magnetic field.
The vertical component of the velocity is unchanged when the particle elastically hits the insulating plate, but the horizontal component reverses direction.
After the bounce, the particle’s velocity is vx’ = –v0/√2 (to the left) and vy’ = v0/√2 (still downward).
The particle continues the same circular path, but it is now moving along the lower half of that circle.
For the particle to leave the magnetic region exactly at point f, the horizontal chord of its circular path between c and f must equal 2d and subtend a 90° central angle.
Magnitude of the magnetic induction: B = mv0 / (2 q d).
